summary: A video analysis of Coachin5ite's exploration of early new moon sightings and their potential impact on the sacred calendar and the transition between seasons.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static image with a bright blue background displaying a "New Moon Report" from the website "iofyahweh.org." At the top, the title "NEW MOON REPORT" is prominently displayed in bold black letters. Below the title, there is an artwork by Susan Lobert, depicting a desert scene with cacti silhouetted against a sunset sky, accompanied by Hebrew text. The main body of the text provides details about the new moon report for June 18, 2023, specifying that it is the 4th New Moon starting the 4th month using the Harvest method for Abib. The text also mentions that the moon was sighted in Arizona and California. The information is presented in a combination of black and pink text, with the date and location details highlighted in pink. The video maintains this static image throughout, with no changes or movements observed between frames.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself and mentioning "breaking news". He says that in the video he will be talking about "the recent sightings of the new moon". His tone is conversational and energetic. This is accompanied by loud ambient sounds from the outdoors. Birds are chirping. Then the speaker says "Now on June the 20th, I woke up in the midst of my day of remembrance celebration" for those who follow his channel.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a webpage titled "New Moon Report" from iofyahweh.org, featuring artwork by Susan Lobert. The artwork depicts a desert scene with cacti silhouetted against a twilight sky, accompanied by Hebrew text. The webpage provides a table of new moon reports for June 18, 2023, after sunset, marking the 4th New Moon of the 4th month using the Harvest method for Abib. The moon was sighted in Arizona and California. Additional information includes a video link on how to sight new moons and a note explaining that sightings reported for the second day are not listed if two or more reliable witnesses report on the first day. The video then transitions to a table listing various locations and their respective sighting reports, with entries such as "Clear, no sighting," "No clouds, slight haze, not seen," and "Sighted by 2 people at 8:16 pm." The video concludes with a message thanking viewers for their understanding, signed by Rich Lobert.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker talking about blowing his shofar and receiving a report of an early sighting of the new moon. He mentions previous instances of early sightings, including one in 2022, and how they were able to disprove them and stay on track. He speaks in a conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a mobile device displaying a webpage from "iofyahweh.org" with a focus on a table titled "New Mo..." (New Moon). The table contains rows with the heading "date:" followed by "MST" (Mountain Standard Time) and "PT" (Pacific Time), with some entries filled with the date "18 June 2023." The time on the device is 9:35, and the battery is at 48%. The scene transitions to another part of the webpage, showing a list of locations with corresponding dates and notes about moon sightings, such as "Sighted by 1 person at 9:27 pm" and "Clear, no sighting." The time changes to 9:36, and the battery remains at 48%. The next frame shows a blue background with text that reads "18 June 2023 New Moon, Angwin, CA (SP)" and a table of new moon reports for various locations, including Arizona and California, with dates and notes about sightings. The time is now 9:37, and the battery is still at 48%. The video concludes with a blue background featuring artwork by Susan Lobert, detailing the "TABLE OF NEW MOON REPORTS FOR 18 June 2023 after sunset, 4th New Moon starting the 4th month (Harvest method for Abib)." It mentions that the moon was sighted in Arizona and California, and includes a link to a video on how to sight new moons. The time remains 9:37, and the battery is at 48%. Throughout the video, the focus is on the information related to the new moon sighting on June 18, 2023, with no people or environmental details visible.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing moon sightings, specifically in Phoenix, Arizona and Aguin, California, including an absence of reports from Santa Clarita, with a conversational tone. The speaker continues listing dates of the sightings, expressing surprise that the moon was cited earlier than expected. He mentions reporting and disproving claims using scripture but states that July 18 sighting is more challenging to disprove. The speaker speculates this could indicate being in spring longer than expected, then prompts the listener to look at Enoch to verify the plausibility of these sightings. The clip ends with static noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screen displaying the title "Holy Bible KJV with Apocrypha" accompanied by a white cross symbol on a gray background, indicating the app's focus on the King James Version of the Bible, including the Apocrypha. The time on the device is 9:38 AM, and the battery is at 47%. The scene transitions to a close-up of a Bible verse from Matthew 28, detailing the events of the resurrection, with the text in English. The user interface shows a search bar at the top, suggesting the app's functionality for searching specific verses or books. The video then shifts to a list of books from the Bible, starting with Ecclesiastes and ending with Revelation, with the user scrolling through the list, highlighting the app's comprehensive coverage of the biblical texts. The final frames show a list of Apocryphal books, including Susanna, Bel and the Dragon, Prayer of Manasseh, 1 Maccabees, 2 Maccabees, Enoch, Jasher, and Jubilees, indicating the inclusion of these texts in the app. The consistent background and user interface elements throughout the video emphasize the app's organized and user-friendly design for accessing biblical content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker promoting a Bible app, noting that it includes the King James Bible, apocrypha, and hidden books. He sounds informative and engaging. Following his speech, there's a distinct sound of someone manipulating a phone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a smartphone screen displaying a search bar at the top with the word "Enoch" typed in, and a grid of numbered buttons below it, ranging from 1 to 53. The time on the phone reads 9:38, and the battery is at 47%. The user scrolls down to reveal a page titled "Enoch 71," which contains a passage about the revolutions of the luminaries of heaven, explained by Uriel, a holy angel. The text is in English and discusses the periods and names of the luminaries, with the number 71 prominently displayed in red at the top of the page. The user continues to scroll, revealing more text under the heading "Enoch 72," which describes the law of an inferior luminary, the moon, and its relationship with the sun. The passage details the moon's light, its periods, and its interaction with the sun's light. The user scrolls further, showing additional verses that describe the moon's light in relation to the sun, its rise and set, and its periods. The time on the phone changes to 9:39 as the user continues to scroll through the text. The video then transitions to a YouTube comment from a user named "Darak iBar," asking "WHO KNOWS THIS ONE?" with a thinking face emoji. The comment is displayed over the text from "Enoch 72," which continues to describe the moon's light and its relationship with the sun. The video concludes with the YouTube comment still visible, while the text from "Enoch 72" remains on the screen, providing a detailed account of the moon's light and its periods.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a section from First Enoch, promising to discuss the Book of the Revolutions of the Luminaries of Heaven and the new moon. His tone is instructional, aiming to clarify certain translations for the listener. He mentions using a Lawrence translation while acknowledging others might be clearer. He plans to talk about this topic in future videos. A faint sound of birds chirping is audible in the background. The male speaker then transitions to a particular verse, dismissing the preceding verses as general information before briefly mentioning the band "Rock Alba" may have released a new song, demonstrating a brief digression from the initial topic.

events_list.video_caption: The video displays a series of frames from a digital device, showing a text document titled "Enoch 72." The text is in English and discusses the phases of the moon and its relationship with the sun. The document is divided into numbered verses, with verses 6, 7, 8, and 9 visible in the frames. The text describes the moon's light as being divided into fourteen portions, with the moon rising with the sun and receiving half a portion of light. It also mentions that the moon sets with the sun and that on certain nights, it is dark in its fourteen portions. The background of the document is white, and the text is black, making it easy to read. The device's status bar at the top of the screen shows the time as 9:40 and the battery level at 47%. The video does not show any people, objects, or environment beyond the digital screen displaying the text. The only visual change between frames is the slight progression of the text, indicating that the document is being scrolled through.
events_list.audio_caption: A man with a calm, focused speaking tone begins by referencing verse seven, describing how the new moon works in relation to the sun's rising and setting. He explains how they rise together initially and the need to use this information when visibility is hindered. Continuing, he elaborates that on the day of the new moon, the sun and moon will rise together, while on the previous day, they will set together. Then, on the evening when the moon is visualized, they will no longer set together, providing space to see the new moon.

events_list.video_caption: The video displays a series of frames featuring a digital screen with text from the biblical book of Enoch, specifically chapter 72. The text is presented in a white font on a black background, with the title "Enoch 72" at the top. The content discusses the division of light and the moon's relationship with the sun, mentioning portions of light and the moon's rise and set. The time displayed on the screen is 9:43, and the battery level is at 46%. The frames are static, with no visible changes or movements, and the environment is not discernible due to the close-up focus on the text. The text is in English, and there are no people or objects visible in the frames. The atmosphere is informational, focusing solely on the text's content.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing verifying the sighting of a new moon, aiming to disprove it but finding that is not the case. His tone is conversational.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a smartphone screen displaying a text passage from Enoch 72, discussing the division of light and the moon's rise and set with the sun. The text is in English, with phrases like "Half of it is in extent seven portions" and "And in a day it receives a seventh portion." The scene transitions to a Google search page with the query "moon, civil twilight beginning and..." visible, leading to search results for "Sunrise & Sunset / Moonrise & Moonset" and "Moonrise and Moonset Calculator." The next frame shows a webpage from the U.S. Naval Observatory titled "Daily Sun Statistics BOS JUN 2023," detailing sunrise and sunset times for June 2023, with a note about small differences in calculations. The video then zooms in on the table of times, highlighting specific dates and times, such as "05:07" and "20:20" for June 9th, and "05:08" and "20:25" for June 23rd. The final frame shows a close-up of the table, focusing on the times for June 10th to June 24th, with the times remaining consistent for several days, indicating a steady sunrise and sunset schedule. The video maintains a focus on the smartphone screen throughout, with no visible people or environmental details, emphasizing the textual and numerical information displayed.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by suggesting to examine information on a specific website, then redirects to a potentially quicker method by consulting National Weather Services for sun and moon tables. He then highlights the sun's rise and set times for June 19th, 2023, noting similarities across the 18th, 19th, and 20th, before proceeding to examine the moon data.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a weather.gov webpage displaying a detailed hourly forecast for a specific location, showing the time, temperature, and other weather-related data. The interface includes a search bar at the top, with the URL visible, and the time displayed on the device is 9:45. The battery level is at 45%, and the device is connected to Wi-Fi. The forecast data is presented in a tabular format, with columns for the hour, time, and temperature, and the background is a light gray color. The video then transitions to a screenshot of a Bible verse from the book of Enoch, chapter 72, verses 6 to 9, displayed on a digital device. The text is in English, with the chapter and verse numbers highlighted in orange. The verse discusses the moon's light and its relationship with the sun, mentioning the moon receiving half a portion of light when the sun rises. The background of the text is white, and the device's time is still 9:45, with the battery level unchanged at 45%. The video concludes with the same screenshot of the Bible verse, with the time on the device now showing 9:46, indicating a one-minute progression from the previous frame. The verse continues to describe the moon's period and its darkness on certain nights, maintaining the same visual layout and background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker who is referring to someone named Enoch. He describes what happened on the 18th, stating "the moon rose with the sun". The speaker references that the sun was at "5:04" and the moon rose at "5:01". He continues to quote verse seven, explaining that "when the sun rises, the moon rises with it, receiving a half a portion of its light". He then references the previous verse. The tone is conversational with a didactic feel.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a smartphone screen displaying a weather.gov webpage, showing a table with times and numbers, likely related to weather data. The time on the phone is 9:46, and the battery is at 45%. The scene transitions to a close-up of a text passage from the Book of Enoch, chapter 72, discussing the moon's phases and its relationship with the sun. The text is displayed in a white font on a light background, with the chapter number highlighted in orange. The time on the phone changes to 9:47, and the battery remains at 45%. The video then returns to the weather.gov webpage, showing the same table with times and numbers, now with the time on the phone at 9:48 and the battery at 44%. The final scene shows a calendar interface with the date set to June 18, 2023, and the time at 9:48:38 am. The calendar interface includes options to select different dates and times, with additional information about the moon's position and phase displayed below. The video concludes with the calendar interface still visible, with the date and time unchanged.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker analyzing data related to the sun and moon, specifically their setting times, emphasizing the fact that they set together and rose together. The speaker also refers to what Enoch says about it. The speaker then shifts the discussion to the sighting of the new moon, mentioning how the moon receives a portion of its light. After this, the speaker refers to a weather website indicating that some requirements were met except for the light portion. The speaker then moves on to an app and goes back to the 18th, noting sunset and the amount of light.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a mobile application interface displaying astronomical data for the date 18 Jun 2023, Sunday, at 7:00:38 pm. The interface features a large black circle representing the moon, surrounded by a starry night sky background. The moon is depicted as a waxing crescent with 0.7% illumination. The app provides detailed information, including the moon's rise time at 4:48 am, set time at 7:50 pm, altitude at +7°56'22", azimuth at 297°17'33", transit time at 12:19 pm, and its position in the Zodiac Cancer. The moon's age is listed as 20 hours, 23 minutes, and 31 seconds, with a distance of 248,179 miles. The interface also includes navigation options for viewing the moon, sun, planets, sphere, sky, and orbits. The video captures the interface at different times, with the time on the phone changing from 9:49 to 9:51 pm, and the battery level decreasing from 44% to 43%. The interface remains consistent throughout, with no significant changes in the displayed data or background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with an earnest male speaker addressing the listener directly, noting a subject is "a big deal" due to the sacred calendar and the timing of the sun and moon's convergence. He suggests that the new moon sighting on June 18th is too early, hinting at an extended Spring season. He notes the cold weather he is experiencing in West Virginia and encourages collaboration and information sharing to clarify this matter, emphasizing the importance of accuracy for upcoming observances. He continues to encourage listeners to work together in the comment section to get everything worked out and look for future videos because the topic is extremely important. Finally, he asks listeners to pray for them as they travel toward DC, suggests that any video suggestions can be posted for their consideration. The speaker expresses his appreciation and delivers a final blessing.
